revision.text:
{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== * 1 3/4 [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] all-purpose [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 2 T. [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Baking Soda|baking soda]] * 1 1/2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Cream of Tartar|cream of tartar]] (or baking powder) * 1/2 tsp. [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Cinnamon|cinnamon]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Nutmeg|nutmeg]] * 1 tsp. [[Cookbook:Vanilla Extract|vanilla extract]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Buttermilk|buttermilk]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Eggs|eggs]], separated * 1/4 cup [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] (optional) * 1 cup frozen [[Cookbook:Blueberry|blueberries]]
==Procedure==
# Sift together flour, sugar, baking powder, cream of tartar, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg. Set aside. # Whisk together buttermilk, butter and egg yolks in a large bowl. Beat flour mixture onto buttermilk mixture. Mix in blueberries. # Beat egg whites in a small bowl until stiff, but do not let dry peaks form. Fold into pancake batter. # Heat a large pan or griddle over medium heat. Lightly spray or brush with vegetable oil. Ladle in a cup of batter for each pancake; cook until set and bubbly on the top. Turn pancake over, cook for 1 more minute. # Serve warm with whatever topping you prefer.
[[Category:Pancake recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pan fried recipes]] [[Category:Blueberry recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

I'm not sure this should be categorized in Category:Recipes since it's not actually a recipe, but a listing of recipes. [[User:Kellen|Kellen]] 20:33, 10 July 2005 (UTC)
I really don't think North American cuisine should dominate this cookbook. The US is not a prime example of good cuisine. --[[User:81.104.235.62|81.104.235.62]] 10:43, 25 September 2006 (UTC)

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == *1 [[cookbook:cabbage|cabbage]], chopped *3 [[cookbook:garlic|garlic]] cloves, minced *3 large [[cookbook:beet|beet]]s, cubed (or 2 cans of beets) *5 large [[cookbook:carrot|carrot]]s, chopped *1 large [[cookbook:onion|onion]], chopped *4 stalks of [[cookbook:celery|celery]], chopped *2 lb. [[cookbook:meat|meat]], cubed *1 lb. stew bones *3 [[cookbook:lemon|lemon]]s (optional) *2 24 oz. cans crushed [[cookbook:tomato|tomato]]es * cup [[cookbook:sugar|sugar]] (optional)
== Procedure == # If you are using fresh beets, you first need to place them in boiling water for between 90 minutes and two hours. For better flavor bake at 350 F for 90 minutes. When they are soft enough that a fork will go in easily then they are done. Put them in a sink or large bowl full of cool water. Once they are cool pick up a beet and press your thumbs into the skin to start peeling them, sometimes they are not soft enough for this and you just need to cook them longer. If you use canned beets they will be ready right out of the can. # While the beets are cooking you should start cooking the meat. Place the meat and bones into a large 12 qt. stock pot. Add the two cans of crushed tomatoes and a similar quantity of water. Stir it up and bring to a boil. # While the meat and beets are cooking chop up all of the vegetables, mince the garlic and squeeze the lemons. # After the meat has been boiling for between an hour and 90 minutes then you should add all of the vegetables except the beets which are still cooking, the lemon juice and the sugar. # Finish peeling and cubing the beets, when the simmering vegetables are soft add the beets, stir well. Then add as much or as little lemon juice and sugar as you like, to suit your own taste. Cook for five more minutes and its done.
[[Category:Stew recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Beet recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Cabbage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Boiled recipes]]

revision.comment: /* Notes, tips, and variations */ Adjusted capitalization of cream cheese cat.
revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|Cuisine of the USA]] {{recipesummary| | Category = Cheesecake recipes | Servings = 10 | Time = 40 min | Rating = 3 | Energy = 807 Cal | Image = [[File:Chocolate cheesecake with decoration.jpg|180px]] }}
'''Chocolate cheesecake''', rich in both chocolate and cheese. It is noticeably less sweet than many other American desserts, and somewhat more complicated.
==Helpful equipment== *[[Cookbook:Mixer|Electric mixer]] *[[Cookbook:Springform Pan|Springform pan]]
==Ingredients== ===Crust=== *5 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|Tbs]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]], melted *2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] chocolate wafer crumbs, or the equivalent in chocolate [[Cookbook:Cookie|cookies]] or chocolate [[Cookbook:Graham Cracker|Graham crackers]] ===Filling=== *3 packages (8 [[Cookbook:Ounce|ounces]] (235g) each) [[Cookbook:Cream Cheese|cream cheese]], at room temperature *1 cup brown [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]], packed *5 large [[Cookbook:Egg|egg]]s *4 ounces (215g) (4 squares) [[Cookbook:Chocolate|semisweet chocolate]], melted ===Frosting=== *6 ounces (150g) (6 squares) semisweet chocolate, melted * cup [[Cookbook:Sour Cream|sour cream]]
==Procedure== #Place rack in center of the oven. Preheat oven to 150 C (300 F). #If starting with whole cookies, crackers, or wafers, place them in a sturdy plastic bag a few at a time and crush using a [[Cookbook:Rolling Pin|rolling pin]], or grind using a [[Cookbook:Food Processor|food processor]]. #Mix together chocolate crumbs and melted butter. #Press crumb mixture into bottom and sides of 9-inch springform pan. #In a large bowl, beat together sugar and eggs at medium speed, slowly adding cream cheese, until smooth and fluffy. #Spoon half of cream cheese mixture into crust. #Melt 4 ounces of chocolate using a [[Cookbook:Double Boiler|double boiler]] or, with care, a [[Cookbook:Microwave Oven|microwave]]. Stir into remaining cream cheese mixture until well blended. #Drizzle over batter in crust. Draw a spoon or other implement through the batter a few times to make swirls. Spread evenly. #Bake cheesecake for 50 minutes. After the first 30 minutes has gone by, place aluminum foil on top to prevent cracking and scorching. #Cool completely. #Cover with plastic wrap, and chill for about 2 hours, up to several days. #Transfer cheesecake to a serving plate. #Uncover cheesecake; carefully remove side of pan. === Frosting === #Melt remaining chocolate. #Mix with sour cream. #Spread over cake, and chill to set.
==Notes, tips, and variations== *Brown sugar is not absolutely necessary (can substitute granulated), but it provides better flavor. *If no electric mixer is available, the cream cheese can be mixed with egg yolks one-at-a-time before the whites are added. Unless you find separating eggs extremely difficult, this will be worthwhile for the effort saved in mixing. *Without a springform pan, a cake this stiff will require that at least the first piece be broken up in the process of serving. Fortunately, it's often easy to find someone who [[Cookbook:Aesthetics|doesn't care]]. *Without aluminum foil, the top of the cake will crack and brown somewhat, but frosting covers it effectively, making it practically unnoticeable.
[[Category:Vegetarian recipes]] [[Category:American recipes]] [[Category:Cream cheese recipes]] [[Category:Cheesecake recipes]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes]] [[Category:Baking recipes]] [[Category:Halal recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]]

revision.text:
{{Cookbook help page}} This page describes policies for pages in the [[Cookbook]]. It is a "living document" so it will change over time to reflect the standards created by Cookbook [[Cookbook:Contributors|contributors]]. ==Recipe Formatting== Recipes should be formatted according to the [[Cookbook:Policy/Recipe template|recipe template]]. == Pages needing work == Pages which need work should be tagged with the {{cookwork}} template, and will appear in [[:Category:Cookbook pages needing work]]. When a recipe has been sufficiently improved, the template should be removed. ==Naming Conventions== ===Cookbook Pages=== ==== Case ==== The de-facto naming convention for Cookbook pages is [[w:Title case|title case]]. ==== Name ==== Recipes should be named according to their traditional name, their origin, or their ingredients. Avoid naming recipes for people, unless it is a well-known recipe by that name. Recipes with a non-English name that have a common English name should be named with their common English name. For example, the primary name for [[Cookbook:Khaeng Keaw Wan]] should be [[Cookbook:Thai Green Curry]]. If necessary or desired a redirect from the name in the original language can be created. In cases where the non-English name is the common name, that name should be used, as in [[Cookbook:Huevos Rancheros]]. Recipes names with special characters ([[w:Diacritic|diacritics]], etc) should be primarily spelled with simple [[w:ASCII|ASCII]] characters and a redirect should be created with the special characters included. ==== Special Diets ==== Recipes for a [[Cookbook:Special Diets|special diet]] which are substantially adjusted variations of a normal recipe should be denoted by the diet name in parentheses after the name of the recipe. A vegan variation of [[Cookbook:Chili]] would be [[Cookbook:Chili (Vegan)]]; a gluten-free variation of [[Cookbook:Brownie]] would be [[Cookbook:Brownies (Gluten-Free)]]; a lactose-free variation of [[Cookbook:Milkshake]] would be [[Cookbook:Milkshake (Lactose-Free)]]. Recipes which adhere to a special diet, but are not variations for that specific diet ''should not'' be named in this fashion; instead only the appropriate category should be added. Trivial variations should be listed on the recipe page itself. ==== Duplicate Recipes and Disambiguation Pages ==== When there is more than one recipe for a single type of food, there are several ways to resolve the situation: # If one recipe is of poor quality, delete it. # If one recipe can be expressed as a variation upon the other, include it in the variations section and delete the original. # If the recipes can be merged into a single recipe, merge them and delete the originals. # Create a disambiguation page for the 'abstract' type of food (using the {{cookdp}} template as a header) and give each recipe a unique name. In the last case, the distinguishing name should be as descriptive of the unique qualities of the recipe as possible. For example, a disambiguation page is [[Cookbook:Lasagne]] which links to [[Cookbook:Traditional Lasagne]], [[Cookbook:Ricotta Lasagne]], and [[Cookbook:Lasagne with bean sauce]]. If there is not an appropriately descriptive way to distinguish the recipes, roman numerals should be used, as in [[Cookbook:Hummus I]]. ===Cookbook Categories=== Cookbook-related categories are not entirely standardized, but these generally seem to be in the "normal" [[w:Wikipedia:Naming conventions (capitalization)|wikipedia form]] of capitalized first letter, lowercased first letter elsewhere (except with proper nouns). For recipe categorization by ingredient, origin, diet, meal type, and recipe type classifications there is a tendency to use the "___ recipes" format e.g.: * [[:Category:Egg recipes]] (by ingredient) * [[:Category:Italian recipes]] (by origin) * [[:Category:Vegan recipes]] (by diet) * [[:Category:Cake recipes]] (by recipe type) * [[:Category:Dessert recipes]] (by meal type) For ingredient categorization, a plural form is generally used, e.g.: * [[:Category:Fats and oils]] * [[:Category:Cheese]] ==Featured Recipe and Ingredient== First, please know and understand, the 'Featured recipe' and 'Featured ingredient' categories are actually just repositories for links to the complete versions of recipes and ingredients that either: * are currently in the rotation to be displayed on the main Cookbook page; or * may have formerly been in the rotation to be displayed on the main Cookbook page, but are now 'retired'. Adding a Featured recipe or Featured ingredient category tag to a recipe does not, by any means, put that recipe or ingredient on the current list of recipes or ingredients that can be displayed on the main Cookbook page. ===Selection=== Cookbook contributors and users should who would like to suggest that a particular recipe or ingredient be displayed on the main Cookbook page are welcome to tag worthy modules with [[:Category:Featured recipe candidates]] or [[:Category:Featured ingredient candidate]]. 'Featured recipes candidates' and 'Featured ingredients candidates' should be chosen to highlight the potential of the [[Cookbook]]. They should therefore be well written and wikified. In addition, each Featured recipe candidate should: * have a picture of the finished recipe (if possible) * follow the [[Cookbook:Policy/Recipe template|recipe template]] * have a recipe summary (see template above) * have proper categories (by ingredient, diet, region, etc as appropriate) * be an entire food item (i.e. not a component as in pie crust, sauces) And each Featured ingredient candidate should: * have a picture of the ingredient * have proper categories (by ingredient, diet, region, etc as appropriate) ===Procedure=== To rotate the Featured recipe and the Featured ingredient shown on the main Cookbook page [http://en.wikibooks.org/w/wiki.phtml?title=Cookbook:Table_of_Contents&action=purge click here]. This will allow you, and everyone throughout the world who accesses the main Cookbook page thereafter, to see a different, randomly selected, Featured recipe or Featured ingredient from the rotation. Actually adding to the list of recipes or ingredients in the rotation of recipes and ingredients shown on the main cookbook page can be problematic: * It is not presently possible to adjust the list of Featured recipes displayed on the main Cookbook page, primarily because the same rotation is also included in the main Wikimedia page and is carefully controlled for that reason. * To add to the list of Featured ingredients displayed on the main Cookbook page see [[Template:Featured ingredient]]. To prepare you in advance, it requires a bit of programming knowledge, a previously researched candidate, the name of an image, ready to cut and paste, the prior composition of a suitable one sentence summary, and several other steps to be successful. ==Available Cookbook-Related Templates== : ''See also [[:Category:Cookbook templates]]'' {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" |- ! Its arguments are in the order they are displayed. #{{Seasonality}}: #* The numbers entered are 1,2 or 3 for each month. 1 means the ingredient is not in season, 2 means the ingredient is not at its best, but is grown by natural means and 3 means the ingredient is in season. These values are entered for the northern hemisphere. The values for the southern hemisphere are automatically rotated 6 months. #* Should preferably be accomplished by a small paragraph explaining the details of the seasonality of the ingredient. The page should also: #** be tagged with one or more of [[:Category:Spring ingredients]], [[:Category:Summer ingredients]], [[:Category:Autumn ingredients]], [[:Category:Winter ingredients]] or [[:Category:Ingredients available all year]]. #** be added to the tables on the [[cookbook:Seasonality|seasonality page]]. #{{SeasonalitySpec}} is used to enter the values for the southern hemisphere manually. The template has 24 number fields one per month per hemisphere, from Jan to Dec, northern hemisphere first. [[Category:Cookbook|!]]

revision.comment: [[Van Dwelling:Dating]] moved to [[Van Dwelling/Dating]]: fixed NC
revision.text:
The question of dating for Van Dwellers really has two sides to it. First, it can possibly scare some people when they discover they are dating a van dweller. Second, it can possibly scare a van dweller to be dating.
Many books about dating provide advice that is applicable to van dwellers, just as it is to the rest of society. Basically, before even contemplating dating, there are some things to consider:
# Do you have a way to maintain good personal hygiene? # Do you have a steady way to make money? (Printing your own does not count). # Do you have a stable place to live?
These are important questions to ask before beginning dating. It will be very difficult to get dates (or at least second dates) without good personal hygiene. Dating can be very well done on the cheap, but it will occasionally require some amount of money.
The third question may be of most interest to some van dwellers. A very small percentage of the population is open to the idea of dating somebody that they view as "homeless," even though you may not consider yourself homeless. As such, you probably only have 3 options:
# Only date people that accept your chosen mode of living. # Just don't let people know. # Don't date.
Since you're reading this, you probably don't consider #3 an option. Finding people that fit #1 may be difficult, but not impossible. Thus, we go to #2.
Since many people consider honesty to be one of those big cornerstones of a successful relationship, this one can get a bit tricky. Things can get even worse when a dating partner starts to question "why we never go back to your place." Therefore, it may be advisable to let somebody know about your situation after a certain number of dates if you plan on pursuing a steady relationship.
This is strictly a personal philosophy, but I would tell a potential partner somewhere around date number five, if I had any inclination of pursuing a long term relationship. My approach would be to start a discussion about the desire for personal freedom and the escape of rampant consumerism and the rat race, and use that as a segue into explaining my living choice.
Of course, if you pick up your date in at his/her house in your van, then they might perhaps be able to figure it out on their own and simply ask. :)
Considering the fact that you have chosen this mode of living for one reason or another, you may actually end up finding potential partners amongst people that are of similar mindset and inclination. If this is an idea you are open to, consider plugging into your local "alternative" community. Most cities have some semblance of a community of people interested in simpler lifestyles, reduced consumerism, and some sort of activism related to such concepts. Participating in groups, activities, and gatherings for these sort of things could provide a plugin to a pool of eligible partners that are open to the van dwelling lifestyle.
[[Category:Van Dwelling]]

Uhm, not sure if you are aware of this, but you might want to check out the existing [[Japanese|Wikibook on Japanese]]. - [[User:Lynx7725|Lynx7725]] 02:57, 11 July 2005 (UTC)
== ??? ==
Well, yes I am aware... Me, together with a small interest group are making a course, based on guidelines i posted, that will utilize the text already there, and add much more content. there are real people here waiting for this course, so it is planned to release weekly. Please tell, just which part exactly you do not like. --[[User:Lastguru|Lastguru]] 04:09, 11 July 2005 (UTC)
== want to contribute? ==
just in case my first statement was too excluding, noone stops other people contributing to the new lesson thread... I hope when there will be some content (in, like 4 months) it will be possible to make these the front-page lessons... will see...--[[User:Lastguru|Lastguru]] 04:24, 11 July 2005 (UTC)
== Old Grammer lessons ==
Since you seem to be the chief contributer to them, are new lessons being made and the old lessons are obsolete or have you just given up on them? --[[User:Balloonguy|Balloonguy]] 21:20, 3 September 2006 (UTC)
no i didn't gave up on them... the lessons marked as old should be restructurized a little bit. they are still great, and i am hoping to continue them. --[[User:Lastguru|lastguru]] 22:02, 13 September 2006 (UTC)

revision.comment: moved [[Portuguese grammar/Grammar overview]] to [[Portuguese Grammar/Grammar overview]]: Title caseing
revision.text:
Portuguese grammar is similar to the grammar of other [[w:Romance languages|Romance languages]] (or even English) and like them there is a strong [[w:latin|latin]] structure that is always being reconstructed. The learner shall find archaic constructions being replaced by modern ones, mostly in colloquial language but even in formal and standard languages.
Firstly, we shall see that Portuguese has a flexible [[w:Word order|Subject-Verb-Object]] order, just like in English and there is no [[w:Declension|case]] declensation. Adjectives are generally placed after the noun. In some cases, there are some subtle differences in placing them after or before the noun, like in French.
The noun has singular and plural forms, but it is interesting to note that, unlike in English, the adjectives also are declinated. There are just two genders: masculine and feminine. The latin neuter gender was absorbed by the masculine one.
Portuguese verbs are slightly complicated, with lots of [[w:Grammatical tense|tenses]] and [[w:Grammatical mood|moods]]. There are also some tenses which are equivalent: like ''eu fizera'' and ''eu tinha feito'' (I had done).
Some peculiarities are remarkable. The Personal Infinitive verb conjugation is found in few languages, such as [[w:Gallician language|Gallician]] or [[w:Hungarian language|Hungarian]]. Portuguese has also developed the Subjunctive mood in such way doesn't found in other Romance languages and is used even in familiar language. Although, the most special feature of this language is the nasals. The nasal vowels - very abundant - has developed in the same way as in French. But the nasal diphtongues found in no language but Portuguese, probably . Although these diphtongues - o, e - are difficult for foreigners to pronounce, there is usually no confusion if they are mispronouced.
[[../About Portuguese speaking countries|Previous chapter]] [[../Introduction|Up]] [[../Alphabet & Phonology|Next chapter]]
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to help you get started:
* Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * Check out our [[Wikibooks:Help|help]] page if you need additional help. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
Good luck!
''(''<sub>Donovan<sub>|[[User:Geocachernemesis|Geocachernemesis]]|<sup>[[User_talk:Geocachernemesis|Interact]]</sup>'')'' 08:48, 11 July 2005 (UTC)

The three irregular future tense verbs are '''trazer''', '''dizer''' and '''fazer'''. Here are their conjugations below. '''TRAZER - To bring'''
I will bring Eu trar ei
You (s,inf) will bring Tu trar s
He will bring
(also ela, você)		 Ele trar
We will bring Nós trar
 emos
You (p) will bring Vós '''trar'''
 eis
They will bring
(also elas, vocês)		 Eles trar o
'''DIZER - To say'''
I will say Eu dir ei
You (s,inf) will say Tu dir s
He will say
(also ela, você)		 Ele dir
We will say Nós dir
 emos
You (p) will say Vós dir
 eis
They will say
(also elas, vocês)		 Eles dir o
'''FAZER - To do/To make'''
I will do Eu far ei
You (s,inf) will do Tu far s
He will do
(also ela, você)		 Ele far
We will do Nós far
 emos
You (p) will do Vós '''far'''
 eis
They will do
(also elas, vocês)		 Eles far o
[[Category:Portuguese]]

== Blender 2.36 HotKeys ==
Ok, I converted this Hotkeys from official [http://www.blender.org/modules.php?op=modload&name=documentation&file=index Blender PDF] file. Please use official Hotkeys names in your articles! --[[User:Popski|Popski]] 14:21, 3 May 2005 (UTC)
== ideas for organization ==
I'd like to start a discussion about how this book should be organized. Perhaps the organization should be changed, or maybe it should stay the way it currently is. Here's an idea:
Create a page for each shortcut. The URL would be formatted very specifically; for example:
[[Blender 3D: Hotkeys/Edit Mode/EKEY]]
[[Blender 3D: Hotkeys/Vertex Paint Mode/VKEY]]
[[Blender 3D: Hotkeys/Object Mode/SHIFT-DKEY]]
This way there could be very detailed information about each of the shortcuts in the different modes.
Then on the Mode Pages, for example the Edit Mode page, the shortcuts could be listed by function....
'''Edit Mode'''
'''''Mesh Modeling'''''
A
*AKEY - select all
E
*EKEY - extrude
etc...
: It's good idea to explain more detailed information about every HotKey, maybe even with examples or links to tutorial examples, but I think that is also good to have all HotKeys in one place (as it is) and from here links to more detailed explanations as you said [[User:Spiderworm|Spiderworm]]. I would like to see here also keyboard drawing with color marked HotKeys large enough that can be printed and used on actual keyboard. --[[User:Popski|Popski]] 17:30, 18 May 2005 (UTC)
:: I just learned something using Template:whatever and <nowiki>{{whatever}}</nowiki>, let me try it out, I think this will help. --[[User:Spiderworm|Spiderworm]] 13:28, 19 May 2005 (UTC)
::: Check this out. Follow the subpages I've created and take a look at the way these <nowiki>{{templates}}</nowiki> work. We can then embed the same hotkey instructions on any Blender book page anywhere in wikibooks using the <nowiki>{{templates}}</nowiki>. Check it out: http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Blender_3D:_HotKeys/new
: Cool! This looks nice and useful! --[[User:Popski|Popski]] 13:59, 22 May 2005 (UTC)
== Blender 2.37a HotKeys Update ==
New HotKeys are marked with <font color=red>*</font color>. --[[User:Popski|Popski]] 13:21, 1 Jul 2005 (UTC)

It's not at all uncommon to require information concerning rotation on a robot, whether from arm or manipulator axis motion to drive wheel speed. Rotary encoders can be found in several varieties, most commonly mechanical or using photodetectors. In mechanical encoders, electrical contacts periodically connect, usually to drive a terminal high or low. These electrical pulses are then used for information. Photodetector encoders can be made smaller and operate much quicker. Typically, a reflective sensor will shine on a marked reflective surface, or a photointerruptor will shine through a disc with transparent and opaque sections, such that the amplitude of received light causes high and low electrical pulses in the receiver. These pulses are then decoded by external circuitry.
==Encoding== Depending on the type and reliability of information needed, the patterning on the rotary encoder will be increasingly complex. If only rotational speed is required, a simple alternating pattern will do, but if both speed and direction are needed, more encoded information is required. Encoding position will inherently yield information regarding velocity and direction, as comparing the direction of change in position will give direction of rotation, where the change in position with respect to time will (by definition) indicate speed. The specific type of position encoding will depend on the precision required, as well as the reliability: how much of an error in measured rotational position due to an error in reading the encoded information, is acceptable in the application.
==Measuring Rotational Speed== [[Image:Incremental encoder.gif|thumb|Example of simple speed-detection rotary encoder]] For some applications, only rotational speed needs to be considered. If a toothed wheel which is mechanically limited to spinning a single direction is being measured, the direction is already known, and only the velocity remains. Perhaps a feedback system is being developed for drive speed on a robot, and an encoder on the axle will enable the controller to calibrate speed by varying PWM values; if the controller enables the motor to spin in a specific direction, all it requires is the rotational speed. All that is necessary to measure speed is a single alternating pattern causing the detector to emit a pulsetrain. The pulse rate will be directly proportional to the rotational speed; measuring the time between consecutive rising (or falling) edges and dividing that into the angle of rotation represented by a pulse will yield the rate of rotation.
:<math>\omega \approx {{{2 \pi} \over n} \over {(T_1 - T_0)}}, ~~~ where~n = pulses~per~revolution </math>
If the rate is changing during the time of the measurement, the calculated rate will be an average approximating the instantaneous rate. This is where precision comes into play the more pulses per rotation, the shorter the time between measurements, and the closer the approximation is to correct. Anyone familiar with calculus will recognize that the rate of change of position with respect to time is a derivative, and the definition of the derivative states that as the timestep across which a measurement for approximation is taken approaches zero, the result is equal to the derivative at that time.
:<math>lim~ \Delta t \rightarrow 0 ~~ { { { \theta ( T_0 + \Delta t ) } - { \theta (T_0) } \over {\Delta t }}} = {{d \theta (t)} \over {dt}} = {\omega (t) }</math>
:<math> \Delta t = {T_1 - T_0} </math>
:<math>lim~ (T_1 - T_0) \rightarrow 0 ~~ { { { \theta ( T_0 + (T_1 - T_0) ) } - { \theta (T_0) } \over {{T_1 - T_0} }}} = {{d \theta (t)} \over {dt}} = {\omega (t) }</math>
:<math>lim~ (T_1 - T_0) \rightarrow 0 ~~ { { { \theta (T_1 ) } - { \theta (T_0) } \over {{T_1 - T_0}}}} = {{d \theta (t)} \over {dt}} = {\omega (t) }</math>
:<math> \theta (T_m) = m \frac {2\pi}{n}</math>
:<math> \theta(T_1) - \theta(T_0) = \frac{2\pi}{n}(1 - 0) = \frac{2\pi}{n}</math>
:<math>lim~ (T_1 - T_0) \rightarrow 0 ~~ { { { \theta (T_1 ) } - { \theta (T_0) } \over {{T_1 - T_0}}}} = { {\frac{2\pi}{n} } \over {T_1 - T_0} } = {{d \theta (t)} \over {dt}} = {\omega (t) }</math>
Measuring the difference in the calculated velocities of successive pulses can give an approximation of rotational acceleration as well.
==Measuring Direction== [[Image:Incremental directional encoder.gif|thumb|Two-row encoder for finding speed and direction]] Assume a machine is tuning its PWM routines for powering the drive wheels. The controller obviously needs to know the rotational speed of the wheels so it can determine the speed outputs for given duty cycles. But what if the machine is placed on a hill? It starts to roll backward and the controller sees a substantial rotational speed for no input, which messes up the entire calibration process. If the controller were able to determine that the wheel was spinning backward, it would know to ignore the speed information. In order to determine direction with a rotary encoder, there must be at least two patterns on the disk, so there is a reference for the direction of change. The simplest way to achieve this is with two alternating patters that are half a pulse out of phase with each other.
If the disc is rotating in a particular direction (in this case, such that the pattern slides to the left), the rising (or falling) edge of channel A will be detected before that of channel B; if rotation is in the opposite direction, the edge of channel B will be detected first. By testing for which pattern's edges are detected first, the direction of rotation can be determined. The time between pulses for a single channel can be measured to approximate rotational speed. However, combining detections from the two channels gives an effective pulse rate double that of a single channel, which halves the measuring time and doubles precision. A means of measuring speed and direction with a single channel exists as well. Two receivers are placed on a single channel spaced half a pulse width apart, so that as the disc rotates, one sensor will be in state as the other transitions. The order in which the two sensors transition into a state is dependent on the direction of rotation of the disc.
==Measuring Position== [[Image:Binary_encoder.gif|thumb|Simple binary encoder example]] [[Image:Gray_Code_encoder.gif|thumb|Simple Gray code encoder example]] The simplest way to determine an angular position on a rotary encoder is to divide the disc into segments and imprint each segment with a unique pattern. The more segments the disc is divided into, the more precision is gained in knowing the location at a given time (each segment will cover a span of angles, so there will be uncertainty, but more segments will give fewer degrees per segment). More segments, however, require more unique identifiers, which means a more complex scheme. This discussion is limited to digital-signal encoders, where the possible outputs for any given channel are limited to 0 or 1. This is conducive to a binary encoding scheme, where each segment is imprinted with a unique binary number. The number of unique IDs required depends on the number of segments; the number of channels is equal to log2(n) where n is the number of segments. A disc with 8 segments has a resolution of 360 / 8 = 45 per segment, and requires log2(8) = 3 separate channels. For a doubling of the number of segments, precision is doubled with an increase of only one pattern channel.
==Reliability== One of the problems with using a binary encoding scheme is detector error. There's no guarantee that every channel is going to transition at the same time, which can cause a misread of a segment's ID. If the section of the disc below the detector is transitioning from one segment to the next, briefly the decoder might read only part of the bits correctly. Assume a standard eight-segment binary encoding scheme, where segments are numbered from 0 to 8 sequentially: if the transition from segment 000 to segment 001 doesn't read the rising edge correctly, your read is off by one space, which for the moment is negligible. If, however, it's transitioning from segment 011 to segment 100, and the least significant bit is read in first, briefly your controller will think it's transitioned to 010, in the complete opposite direction. If the most significant bit is read in first, it'll think it jumped from 011 to 111, on the complete opposite side of the wheel. Transition errors when a single bit changes can often be considered negligible, as the error in calculated position is 1. Errors from multi-bit transitions can be catastrophic.
==Gray Code== {| border="0" cellpadding="10" align="right" |- | <!-- Second table to provide spacing around the inner table, can't get it otherwise.... --> {| width="150" align="right" cellpadding="5" border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse;" |- | <small>4-bit Gray code</small> 0000 0001 0011 0010 0110 0111 0101 0100 1100 1101 1111 1110 1010 1011 1001 1000 |} |} Gray code is a specific type of binary pattern in which there is only a single bit changing during a transition from one element to the next. Being a binary pattern, Gray codes use the same number of channels for the same number of specific patterns; they are just ordered differently. Binary uses patterns in a numerically sequential order; Gray code does not. Encoding positions using this method will require additional software or hardware to decode the ID (as a simple binary conversion will not yield a sequentially-ordered set of segments), but the benefits for the reliability of hardware are substantial as only a single bit changes during each transition, then the maximum error in detected position for an error in pattern reception is 1 segment. Gray code can be written out bitwise in much the same way binary can. In binary, the least significant bit alternates from 0 to 1 every step; the next bit alternates every two steps, the next every four and so on. In Gray code, each bit holds a pattern of 0-1-1-0; the least bit holds each element for one step; the next bit holds each two steps, the next four and so on. It can be noticed that two-channel Gray code is identical to the two-channel pattern used to find rotational direction.
{{AltBookCat}}

Prerequisites: Addition
Subtraction deals with the taking away of numbers, like number a from number b so that: a >= b while b > a. Such a case is with:
20 - 10 = 10.
a = 20 and b = 10.
So a - b = 10, a >= b is true, and b > a is initially true.
Subtraction is the inverse of addition, meaning that it is the opposite.
[[Category:Programmed Math]]

revision.comment: [[Programmed Math:rounding]] moved to [[Programmed Math/Rounding]]: comply with [[WB:NP]]
revision.text:
Rounding is a function that deals with a sort of "evening" of numbers, to make them closer to a specific target, say a 5 or a 10, in this we say a number is nicely rounded, or '''round'''.
Here is an example:
Number a is 23.
(a): While our number remains at 23, we could either move it up (to 25) or down (to 20). Since the number is closer to 20, we make the number 20.
(b): Our number is now 26. This number is above 5. And since 30-4 =26, we will increase the number to 30, because of the small gap.
But what about the number 5? For all numbers what include 5, we round them up to the nearest 10.
(c): Number = 25. New number = 30 (after rounding).
[[Category:Programmed Math]]

revision.comment: /* top */clean up, replaced: alot a lot using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
Scientific notation or exponents deals with the simplification of very large or small numbers into easy to read ones. Often used a lot in sciences such as physics or in scientific math, scientific notation (referred to as exponents from here on in for naming conventions) can be used to describe the size of an electron, or the speed of light.
The speed of light in one such example is shown as:
3.0 x 10^8 or 3.0E8 Where 10^8 stands for 10 to the 8th exponent and 10E8 means the same.
The size of an electron could be described as this for an example:
3.45 x 10^-23 or 3.45E-23 Where 10^-23 means 10 to the -23 exponent (E the same), which is actually making it into a fraction, meaning that 3.45 x 10^-23 will be:
<math>\frac{3.45}{100000000000000000000000}</math>
[[Category:Programmed Math]]

Hey! Thanks for the note on my page, but I don't recall making a fuss about making biscuits. They ''are'' super easy. Better than making pancakes, imo. [[User:Kellen|Kellen]] <sup>[[User_talk:Kellen|T]]</sup> 23:30, 16 January 2006 (UTC)

== Pasta e Fagioli == No problem! Good to see sparklin' new recipes! My blasted session timed out again... [[User:Kellen|Kellen]] 17:47, 11 July 2005 (UTC) == Jewish Recipes == I think "Jewish cuisine" would be an appropriate subsection of [[Cookbook:Cuisine]], though I'm sure there's some overlap into other regional cuisines. You may want to introduce regional sections or lineage sections underneath it, and crosslist common recipes and also crosslist the recipes when the coincide with normal regional cuisine (i.e. not entirely jewish-specific) [[User:Kellen|Kellen]] 17:24, 17 July 2005 (UTC) == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Too Old. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Too Old~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
23:50, 17 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

Stuff to be merged into [[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]]
== Weapon availability at ammunation ==
Weapons become available once you open up a new area of the game or complete a certain mission:
Country Rifle- Complete Body Harvest
Satchel Charges- Complete Against All Odds
Desert Eagle- Open Las Venturas
Combat Shotgun- Complete You've Had Your Chips
Sniper Rifle- Complete Snail Trail
Colt M4- Open the Dessert
AK-47- Open San Fierro
== Vertical bird mission ==
The right analog stick controls the position of the jets. Pushing forward rotates the jets so they point backwards. Pulling back rotates the jets so they point down. The former makes it behave more like a plane, and the latter makes it behave more like a helicopter.
For the first part (air-to-air combat), you probably want the former, for the second part (air-to-ground combat), you probably want the latter.
In both cases, try to get the target in view, press R1 to lock on. When the green crosshair turns red, press L1 to fire missiles.
{{GFDL}}

* And it is not realized up to the end krossbazovost. Support PostgreSQL till now in a condition of planning. That that I expected was not justified. True krossbazovosti do not wait... * Patterns are planned to moving to the catalogue of elements (imho: not the best decision, but we have centralization), the catalogue of elements will get the huge sizes at installation of a plenty of elements. * Now the pattern is added as an element, instead of simple copying in the necessary catalogue. To choose a pattern begins business gemmorojnym (I speak about a choice haljavnyh patterns when much and all would be desirable to look them in operation) * And it is not realized till now multi sajtovost and krossautentifikatsija.
Perhaps while will suffice. It is a lot of defects, but I ask to consider, that it is just the CVS version... And up to bety it is still far. Three weeks. For three weeks much can happen.:i)
But as a whole I am happy. Developers have made much. And still will make much.:i)

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/192.71.40.14|192.71.40.14]] ([[User talk:192.71.40.14|talk]]) to last version by MarkTraceur
revision.text:
{{cookdp}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Cuisine of Italy]] | [[Cookbook:Pasta Recipes|Pasta Recipes]] __NOTOC__
[[File:Lasagna.jpg|thumb|Cooked lasagne on a plate.]]
'''Lasagna''' is a popular oven-baked pasta dish of fresh egg pasta squares. It is a traditional dish from Bologna in Northern Italy, where the sheets are always green through the addition of spinach or nettles to the egg dough. In Bologna, these home made sheets are layered with small amounts of real Bolognese rag (made with both beef and pork, very little tomato and no southern herbs like oregano and basil but a little nutmeg instead) and simialrly small amounts of [[Cookbook:Bchamel Sauce|"besciamella" ]] or bchamel sauce in an oven dish. There are at least 5 layers of pasta dough, and the layers stay separate and do not "merge" together into a mush. A light sprinkling of [[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese| Parmigiano-Reggiano ]], and a few dabs of butter end the dish which is then baked for about half an hour. The use of [[Cookbook:Mozzarella Cheese|Mozzarella]] in place of Bchamel suggests a Neapolitan variation to the original Bologna classic, as does the use of Ricotta.
''Lasagne'' refers to multiple sheets of pasta; ''lasagna'' refers to the dish or to individual sheets of pasta.
In Italy but especially outside, many lasagna variations exist today. Vegetable lasagna, lasagna without bchamel sauce, lasagna without any sauce (just vegetables and/or meat) or even lasagna without sheets of pasta.
When assembling a lasagna, start with the main ingredient (ragu, vegetables, seafood, etc.), add a layer of bchamel sauce, then one layer of lasagne pasta sheets and then the main ingredient again. Continue until the oven dish is full. End with a layer of pasta, spread some bchamel sauce on top and sprinkle the cheese over it.
== The Pasta == When it comes to the pasta dough there is, as always, a choice between home-made pasta and store bought sheets of dried pasta. Since dried pasta is made with just water and flour and home made fresh pasta usually includes eggs, there is a distinct difference in flavour and texture. The main difference, however, comes from ease of use. Making pasta from scratch can be a lengthy process and takes some practice to get it right. See the [[Cookbook:Pasta|pasta]] page for a fresh pasta recipe.
Dried pasta is usually precooked, so it can be put in to the oven dish straight out of the packet.
In the US, pasta sheets generally have a curvy surface. Outside the US, they are almost always flat.
Apart from the plain lasagne sheets, the green ones that Bologna favours are also common. These are called ''lasagne verdi'' and are flavored with spinach. They work well with white sauces ([[Cookbook:Bchamel Sauce|bechamels]] or cream-based sauces and seafood.
== General Guidelines for making Lasagna ==
* Most packaged lasagna need to cook in a preheated oven for 30 to 50 minutes (based on the size) at gas mark 4 (350F/180C).
== Notes, Tips & Variations ==
* Some recipes call for the bchamel sauce to be mixed through the ragu or tomato sauce, while others tell you to layer it between the pasta and the ragu. This seems to be based on personal preference and taste. * Besides sprinkling cheese on top of the lasagna, it's also a good idea to mix some through the bchamel sauce, to give the lasagna some cheese flavor throughout, instead of just on top. Turn the heat off under the bchamel sauce before adding the cheese, or the sauce will become rubbery. * A [[Cookbook:Moussaka|Moussaka]] is essentially a lasagna with slices of eggplant instead of pasta. * A [[Cookbook:Pasta Casserole (Pastitsio)|Pastitsio]], or Greek Lasagna, is a Greek casserole like lasagna where the ragu is combined with tubular pasta, and topped with a [[Cookbook:Bchamel Sauce|bchamel sauce]]. * A [[Cookbook:Scacchi|Scacchi]] or ''mina'' is a lasagna-like dish made during Passover by some Italian and Sephardic Jews, using broth or water-soaked matzo as the starch layer and generally containing ground beef or lamb, spinach or other greens, and other vegetables as ingredients.
== Lasagna Recipes ==
* [[Cookbook:Traditional Lasagne|Traditional Lasagna]] * [[Cookbook:Ricotta Lasagne|Ricotta Lasagna]] * [[Cookbook:Lasagne with bean sauce|Lasagna with bean sauce]]
[[Category:Pasta recipes]] [[Category:Italian recipes]] [[Category:Lasagne recipes]]
== External Links ==
* [http://www.easylasagna.net Lasagna]
[[id:Resep:Lasagna]]

==Naming layout of your Wikiversity course== Hey, I'd like you to have a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming conventions]] and consider giving this course a hierarchy. At the moment it's entirely up to you to show readers what the parent of a page is. And doing it the way you are now you're eventually going to run into conflicts with existing books/pages' names.
Anyway, hope that helps! :) [[User:Master Thief Garrett|Garrett]]<sup>[[User talk:Master Thief Garrett|Talk]]</sup> 22:24, 11 July 2005 (UTC)
==Writing Adolescent Fiction==
Due to your interest in the creative writing wikibooks, you may be interested in [http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Writing_Adolescent_Fiction Writing Adolescent Fiction]. [[User:Cilantrohead|Cilantrohead]] ([[User talk:Cilantrohead|talk]]) 22:22, 1 March 2008 (UTC)

revision.comment: [[Programmed Math:order of operations]] moved to [[Programmed Math/Order of operations]]: comply with [[WB:NP]]
revision.text:
Order of Operations in math is dealing with the order in which you work out an equation, which can solve many problems.
For example:
2 x 3 + 5 = x
In this example, what is x? We could either multiply 2 by 3, then add 5 to it OR we could add 3 and 5 together and multiply that by two. But how do we know?
Using BODMAS we can. BODMAS stands for Brackets Over Division Multiplication Addition Subtraction. This is the order we go in.
So using BODMAS we will multiply first and then add. So it is really:
(2x3) + 5 = x x = 11
Order of operation is also inportant in boolean algebra (see: Boolean Algebra). When a problem needs to be solved, it can be turned into BODMAS form to solve it. For example:
1 AND 1 OR 0 NAND 1. How would this work? If we convert it, it is:
1x1+0x1'= x
So we would go for multiplication first, 1x1 = 1.
so it is now:
1+0x1'=x
We do multiplication again: 0x1 = 0, but because this is the inverse, we make it 1.
So it is now: 1+1 = 2 (or in this case 1, because it is OR).
And our problem gets solved.
[[Category:Programmed Math]]

Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Thanks for helping to fight spam, and carry on the good work. But remember that you shouldn't add a comment to the page after the deletion.
Here are some tips to help you get started:
* Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * Check out our [[Wikibooks:Help|help]] page if you need additional help. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
Good luck!
''(''<sub>Donovan<sub>|[[User:Geocachernemesis|Geocachernemesis]]|<sup>[[User_talk:Geocachernemesis|Interact]]</sup>'')'' 23:43, 11 July 2005 (UTC)

revision.comment: [[Programmed Math:decimals]] moved to [[Programmed Math/Decimals]]: comply with [[WB:NP]]
revision.text:
Decimals (or floating point numbers) are the oposite of fractions, where fractions take the form of a number over a number eg: <math>\frac{1}{2}</math> which is one half.
In decimal format this would be 0.5. Why?
Well one half of 1 is 0.5 since 0.5 * 2 is equal to 1. If we multiply the number at the bottom by the decimal we should get the number at the top. Such as:
<math>\frac{2}{4}</math> Is still one half. <math>2/4 = 0.5</math> since <math>\frac{1}{2} = \frac{2}{4}</math> and <math> 0.5*4 = 2</math>
So the formulae could be: <math>\frac{a}{b}=x</math> and thus <math>x*b = a</math>
[[Category:Programmed Math]]

{|class="boilerplate metadata" cellspacing="0" align="right" style="margin: 0 0 0.5em 1em;" bgcolor="#f3f9ff" border="1px" || '''Note''': This page contains [[w:International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]
[[w:phonetic|phonetic]] symbols in [[w:Unicode|Unicode]].
See [[w:IPA in Unicode#Fonts|IPA in Unicode]]. |}[[Category:Multilingual support templates|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: [[Programmed Math:measuring]] moved to [[Programmed Math/Measuring]]: comply with [[WB:NP]]
revision.text:
Measurement in math is the act of finding the length, width, height etc... of a certain object, different measurement schemes are used for different objects.
eg:
Centimetres for small shapes, Square centimetres for area Centimetres cubed for volume.
There are different ways of measuring geometric shapes, depending on the dimentional qualities of them. For example, measuring a line ----- long, you could count how many dashes there are, and call it 5 dashes long, or you could measure it with a ruler.
But for something like:
------- I I I I -------
You would first use the formula for Area to get the inside size, or use the formula for perimeter. A=LW for a square, So Area = Length * Width
So as <math>4 * 7 = 28cm^2</math>
Which is 28cm squared
For perimeter in a square, you take each side and add them together. So <math>4 + 4 + 7 + 7= 2*4 + 2*7 = 8 + 14 = 22</math>
[[Category:Programmed Math]]

revision.comment: Added cats for Banana, Rum, and Baking, per the recipe. Corrected some capitalization issues.
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Dessert recipes|6|1 ½ hours|2}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Desserts|Desserts]]
Bread Pudding is a British Dessert. This version has banana and chocolate.
==Ingredients== * ¼ cup semisweet [[Cookbook:Chocolate|chocolate]] chips * ¼ cup plus 2 tablespoons spiced [[Cookbook:Rum|rum]] * 4 [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]] * 2 cups [[cookbook:Cream|whipping cream]] * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Vanilla Extract|vanilla extract]] * 5 tablespoons [[cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 16 oz loaf of [[cookbook:Baguette|French bread]] or other non-sour white [[cookbook:bread|bread]] (stale bread is traditionally used) * 2 tablespoons [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] * 3 [[Cookbook:Banana|bananas]]
==Procedure== # In a cup or other small container, add 2 tablespoons of rum to the chocolate chips and soak them until they are needed in step 9 # In a bowl, whisk together the eggs, whipping cream, vanilla extract, ¼ cup rum and 3 tablespoons sugar. # Slice the bread, trim off the crusts and cut it into strips. divide the bread strips into three parts. # Butter a loaf pan # Peel the bananas, cut them in half crosswise and then lengthwise # In a skillet over medium heat, melt the butter and add the banana pieces with 2 tablespoons of sugar. cook 2 minutes, then flip the bananas over and cook the other side for 2 minutes. # Cover the bottom of the loaf pan with bread strips (use 1/3 of the bread strips for this) # Spread half of the banana pieces on top of the layer of bread strips # Spread half of the chocolate chips on top of the bananas # Add another layer of bread strips # Pour half of the egg mix into the loaf pan and let it soak in for a minute. # Add the rest of the bananas, then the rest of the chocolate chips, then the rest of the bread strips. pour the rest of the egg mixture on top # Let the loaf pan sit for about 15 minutes while preheating the oven to 350°F # Bake for 50 minutes. let cool for 10-15 minutes
Serve with Rum Sauce, whipped cream or vanilla ice cream.
[[Category:Dessert recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Pudding and Custard recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Banana recipes]] [[Category:Chocolate recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Rum recipes]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baking recipes]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{IPA notice}} Portuguese alphabet, like in other [[w:Romance languages|Romance languages]] has a natural evolution from latin and so it is not strictly phonetic and has some features inheirited from its history. Although, compared to English or even French it is easy to read and not so hard to write.
==Letters==
The sounds are better explained in the next chapters.

|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;" rowspan = 2|O |style = "background: #99CCFF;" rowspan = 2|o |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Close-mid back rounded vowel|o]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|o as in French m'''o'''t or o as in Spanish n'''o''' |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|total |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|total |- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Open-mid back rounded vowel|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a as in b'''a'''ll or aw as in l'''aw''' |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|lorde |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|lord

|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;" rowspan = 2|S |style = "background: #99CCFF;" rowspan = 2|esse |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless alveolar fricative|s]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|s as in '''s'''ince |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|sela |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|saddle |- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiced alveolar fricative|z]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|z as in zoo |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|casa |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|house

Note: the letter ''q'' is always preceded by a ''u''.
==Digraphs==
[[w:Digraph (ortography)|Digraph]]s is a pair of letters used to sign one sound.
{|border = 0 cellpadding = 3 cellspacing = 2 bgcolor = "#FFFFFF"| |- |style = "background: #009955;"| Digraph |style = "background: #009955;"| Sound ([[w:International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]) |style = "background: #009955;"| Sound (compared to English) |style = "background: #009955;" colspan = 2| Example
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|ch |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless postalveolar fricative|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|sh as in '''sh'''e |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|achar |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|to find
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|lh |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Palatal lateral approximant|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|aprox. ll as in mi'''ll'''ion or gli as in Italian fi'''gli'''o |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|filho |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|son
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|nh |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Palatal nasal|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|aprox. ny as in ca'''ny'''on or as in Spanish ma''''''ana |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|amanh |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|tomorrow
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|qu |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless velar plosive|k]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|c like in a'''cc'''ount |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|questo |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|question
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|rr |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiced uvular fricative|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|h like american '''h'''ello |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|carro |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|car
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|ss |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless alveolar fricative|s]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|s as in '''s'''ince |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|passo |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|step
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|sc |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless alveolar fricative|s]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|s as in '''s'''ince |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|descer |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|go down
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|s |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless alveolar fricative|s]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|s as in '''s'''ince |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|desa |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|go down! |}
==Diacritics==
In Portuguese, a letter with no or with [[w:Diacritic|Diacritic]]s are considered the same thing. So, in alphabetic order, we have: ''entender, tica, Europa''.
{|border = 0 cellpadding = 3 cellspacing = 2 bgcolor = "#FFFFFF"| |- |style = "background: #009955;"| Letter with diacritic |style = "background: #009955;"| Name |style = "background: #009955;"| Sound ([[w:International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]) |style = "background: #009955;"| Sound (compared to English) |style = "background: #009955;" colspan = 2| Example
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"| |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a com acento agudo |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Stress (linguistics)|stressed]] [[w:Open front unrounded vowel|a]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a as in american f'''a'''ther |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|clice |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|calix
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"| |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a com acento grave ([[Portuguese Grammar/Crase|Crase]]) |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Open front unrounded vowel|a]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a as in american f'''a'''ther |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|Fui cidade. |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|I went to the city
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"| |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a com til |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Nasal vowel|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|a as in american wh'''a'''t |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|no |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|no
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"| |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|ce cedilha |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Voiceless alveolar fricative|s]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|s as in '''s'''ince |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|moa |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|girl
|- |style = "background: #99CCFF;"| |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|e com acento agudo |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|[[w:Stress (linguistics)|stressed]] [[w:Open-mid front unrounded vowel|]] |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|ai as in french Pal'''ai'''s or e as in English b'''e'''d |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|pattico |style = "background: #99CCFF;"|patetic

page.title: Cookbook:Table Point Boiled Beef and Vegetables (Tafelspitz)

revision.text:
{{recipe}}
Cooked according to classic preparation rules, Tafelspitz (literally translated: the point of the table) is known to have been Austrian Hungarian Emperor Francis Joseph's favourite meal. Viennese Tafelspitz for Austrians is not only a way to boil beef, but is a whole special culinary science prepared with a special cut of beef. It is not a pot roast. The authentic Tafelspitz requires a custom-cut fresh piece of the hind part of beef (comparable to the American tri tip, also called silver tip); on the North American market, a substitute can be fresh beef chuck brisket (not corned brisket).
The secrets of a juicy Tafelspitz are: heating the water to a rolling boil before the piece of meat is put in the water; the sudden sealing of the meats juices as soon as the meats pores close when the Tafelspitz touches the boiling water; not too much salt, but enough to enhance the meats flavour; a few pieces of vegetables (sometimes also sections of bones with marrow), the right cooking time, and the gentle rolling of the boiling water which will cook but not break the meats fibre. This recipe is a simplified version of this very Austrian dish.
== Ingredients == * 2 pounds (1200g) of either fresh beef brisket, silverside or sirloin-enough water for your suitable Dutch oven pot (about 5 Qt. (700ml) Pot capacity with about 4 Qts. (560ml) Of water) + salt (about tablespoon for every Qt. Of water). * 3 whole cloves [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], slightly crushed, peeled. * 3 whole green (freeze dried) or white [[Cookbook:Pepper|peppercorns]]. * 2 [[Cookbook:Juniper Berry|juniper berries]] (you may substitute with 1 [[Cookbook:Bay Leaf|bay leaf]]). * 3 whole medium size [[Cookbook:Carrot|carrots]], peeled, trimmed (about 4 oz. [110g)]). * 1 small-medium [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]], trimmed, unpeeled, halved (about 2 oz [55g]). * 3 sprigs fresh [[Cookbook:Parsley|parsley]].
== Procedure == # In a suitable covered Dutch oven, bring water to a rolling boil over medium heat. #When the water boils, add meat, garlic, peppercorns, juniper berries, and cover. # Bring the water to a boil again and add carrots, onion, and parsley. #Cover and let everything simmer for 60 minutes. #Turn the meat over, add salt, and let everything cook, covered, for 90 additional minutes. # Switch off the heat and let the meat steep for 20 minutes. #Remove the meat from the broth and cut meat across the grain when you serve it.
Serve Tafelspitz with Apfelkren and your choice of raw and cooked vegetables.
Note :Keep the broth for soups. Cut cold meat leftovers in thin strips and use like a meat salad mixed with raw sliced onions dressed with a simple oil, vinegar, salt and pepper vinaigrette.
How to make Apfelkren (apple horseradish sauce) for Tafelspitz: Combine and blend 1 pound Golden Delicious apples, cored, peeled, grated and cooked until very mushy with 1 tablespoon wine vinegar, 1 tablespoon lemon juice and 3 tablespoons prepared horseradish.
[[Category:Beef recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetable recipes]] [[Category:Boiled recipes]] [[Category:Main course recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

Why are these together? [[User:Notthe9|Notthe9]] 05:20, 12 July 2005 (UTC)
Bobcats are actually a ''type'' of Lynx, so all this information on them being "different" is false. See the [http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761568386/Lynx.html Encarta article]. --[[User:Munchkinguy|Munchkinguy]] 02:45, 2 September 2005 (UTC)
Changed it around a bit, making it clear that bobcats are a kind of lynx. I messed up the layout slightly, but I feel the image I added shows the face of a lynx beautifully. I went and called the ''Lynx Lynx'' and ''Lynx Canadensis'' just plain Lynx, since they are very similar in the first place. Not the best of edits, but I feel it was a step in the right direction. --[[User:BCalchet|BCalchet]] 04:02, 11 September 2005 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* My Questions for who I talk to */
revision.text:
For the interview section, or perhaps just content for the Big Cats issue, I am planning to attempt to solicit an interview with someone at [http://www.livingdesert.org/ The Living Desert Zoo and Gardens] here in the Palm Springs, CA area.
They have one or more: Bobcat Caracal Cheetah Leopard Ocelot Puma Serval
==My Questions for you here== *How should I deal with this? I am thinking of introducing myself as "Mike Graham with (or maybe ''from'') the WikiMedia Foundation," which has an air of legitamacy to it. I hope introducing myself as such would not be to presumptuous.
*I should also probably give myself a title. Contributor sounds a little too informal, it seems to me. Would calling myself a writer for the Foundation be going to far?
:I think either contributor or volunteer sound general enough that they leave a lot of room for interpretation, especially volunteer since you are representing a foundation. --[[User:Laurascudder|Laura Scudder]] | [[User talk:Laurascudder|Talk]] 22:10, 27 July 2005 (UTC)
*Are there any matters of interview etiquitte I should be aware of? Also, how should I dress? (Note: it is very hot here, I'm talking in excess of 110 degrees. I suspect this might be an outdoor, touring interview. At least that's what I'd like, and I think that might be most productive.
:The most important rule I've heard isn't ettiquitte: Never ask a question that can be answered with a yes or no. Rephrasing such a question will get you way more information. --[[User:Laurascudder|Laura Scudder]] | [[User talk:Laurascudder|Talk]] 22:10, 27 July 2005 (UTC)
==My Questions for who I talk to== ::Post suggestions here for questions, or other suggestions. I'll post more details about who I will be interviewing (assuming I will be interviewing somoene) when I get information.
These are the kinds of things I think kids would ask: *What do you feed your cats and how much do they eat? *Which of your cats are considered the most dangerous? *How do the cats get exercise in the zoo? *What types of toys do they have / particularly enjoy? *Where do you get your big cats? *How do you keep them from escaping? *What kind of special care do cubs born in the zoo require?
I might also ask *What are the biggest problems zoos face in caring for big cats? *What question do you wish more people would ask?
This is definitely something where input from someone with a classroom full of our target age would be really helpful. --[[User:Laurascudder|Laura Scudder]] | [[User talk:Laurascudder|Talk]] 22:19, 27 July 2005 (UTC)
:Also if the [[Wikijunior Big Cats/Tigons and Ligers]] is staying, you probably want to ask about Tiger and Lion hybridization in zoos and the ethics of it. --[[User:Laurascudder|Laura Scudder]] | [[User talk:Laurascudder|Talk]] 22:21, 27 July 2005 (UTC)

Things encountered on Linux
*GCC *Makefiles *Tarballs *Bash Scripts *Free Software Licences *Packaging Systems (e.g. deb) *Versioning Systems (e.g. CVS, Subversion)
== Free Software Licences ==
Due to Linux's origins you will find that a lot of packages available for it use various types of free licenses. It is important that you pay attention to these if you are going to be using the code for any further development.
== Tarballs ==
A term referring to a package stored as a file with the extension tar.gz these are often used for distributing source files. They perform a similar function to a zip file.
==Makefiles== A text file used by the make program to create a program. The script used to make a program uses the form program : codefiles command to build
The script clean: rm -f objectfiles program tells make what to delete when the command <tt>make clean</tt> is invoked.
== Versioning Systems ==
In open development processes many people may be working on the same codebase. To ease the complexity of co-ordinating development the code is sometimes stored in a versioning system. This usually consists of a central repository where developers can "check out" (like you check a book out of a library) pieces of code to work on they then work on it and their changes are merged back in when they have finished.
== Links == *[[Computer_programming/Linux_Programming|Linux wikibooks page]] *[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux Linux wikipedia entry]

[[Puzzles]] | [[Puzzles/Set_theory puzzles|Set theory Puzzles]] | A strange set (Russel's paradox) ----
Does the set of all sets that do not contain themselves exist?
[[Puzzles/Set theory puzzles/Russell's Paradox/Hint|hint]]
[[Category:Puzzles]]

[[Puzzles]] | [[Puzzles/Set_theory puzzles|Set theory Puzzles]] | [[Puzzles/Set theory puzzles/Russell's Paradox|A strange set (Russel's paradox)]] | hint ----
In set theory you can specify a set by naming the elements of a set (say <math>a</math>) and giving constraints on them (say <math>cond(a)</math>): <math> \{a | cond(a) \} </math>.
Now try to construct the set of all sets that do not contain themselves in the above notation. If it were to exist, all sets should be unambigously elements of that set or not. Otherwise a contradiction would result. Which set would be most worthwhile to consider?
[[Category:Puzzles]]

1. Cmo ests? - b. Estoy bien.
2. Gracias. - d. De nada.
3. Adis. - e. Hasta luego.
4. Cmo te llamas? - c. Me llamo Thomas.
5. Buenos das. a. Hola. [[Category:Spanish]]
